et: Middle English, from Medieval Latin {it}divinus{/it}, from Latin, soothsayer, from {it}divinus{/it}, adjective {dx_ety}see {dxt|divine:1||}{/dx_ety}

dt: {bc}to discover or locate (something, such as underground water or minerals) usually by means of a {d_link|divining rod|divining rod}

{bc}to seek to predict future events or discover hidden knowledge usually by the interpretation of {d_link|omens|omen} or by the aid of supernatural powers {bc}to practice {d_link|divination|divination} {bc}{sx|prophesy||}

pt: {sc}foresee{/sc} {sc}foreknow{/sc} {sc}divine{/sc} {sc}anticipate{/sc} mean to know beforehand. {sc}foresee{/sc} implies nothing about how the knowledge is derived and may apply to ordinary reasoning and experience.
{sc}foreknow{/sc} usually implies supernatural assistance, as through revelation.

pt.t: if only we could {it}foreknow{/it} our own destinies

pt: {sc}divine{/sc} adds to {sc}foresee{/sc} the suggestion of exceptional wisdom or discernment.

pt.t: was able to {it}divine{/it} Europe's rapid recovery from the war

pt: {sc}anticipate{/sc} implies taking action about or responding emotionally to something before it happens.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French {it}deviner{/it}, from Latin {it}divinare{/it}, from {it}divinus{/it}, noun {dx_ety}see {dxt|divine:1||}{/dx_ety}
shortdef: to discover by intuition or insight : infer
to discover or locate (something, such as underground water or minerals) usually by means of a divining rod
to seek to predict future events or discover hidden knowledge usually by the interpretation of omens or by the aid of supernatural powers : to practice divination : prophesy
